entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 3 (1)
entry.content:
üöÄ  Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)

 

Now that your custom AI agent is deployed and running on SAP AI Core, the next step is to connect it to Joule Studio, SAP‚Äôs conversational AI workspace. In this part, you‚Äôll set up the foundation that allows Joule to communicate securely with your deployed agent.

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Create a Destination for your AI Core endpoint
  • Configure a Joule Environment for Skill deployment
  • Build and test Actions that call your backend APIs

Once these are complete, Joule will be ready to call your backend APIs, and in Part 3 (2), we‚Äôll turn those APIs into an interactive Skill you can deploy and chat with.

 

1. Create Destination

Destinations in SAP BTP act as centralized connection configurations. They store the endpoint URL, authentication details, and headers needed to connect external systems like SAP AI Core.

‚ö†Ô∏èNote: When calling SAP AI Core from Joule Studio, make sure the AI Core destination is configured in the subaccount where Joule Studio is deployed. 

  1. Go to BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations
  2. Click New Destination, and fill in the following details as this example:
  • Name : agent-backend
  • Type: HTTP
  • URL : https://api.<region>.aicore.cloud.sap/v2/inference/deployments/<deployment-id>
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • Client ID / Secret : From your AI Core service key
  • Token Service URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  • AdditionalProperties
    • HTML5.DynamicDestination : true
    • AppgyverEnabled : true
    • URL.headers.AI-Resource-Group : <your-resource-group-name>
    • URL.headers.Content-Type : application/json

 

2. Create Environment for Joule Skills

In SAP Build, Environments act as workspaces where your Joule Skills will be deployed and executed.

  1.  Go to SAP Build ‚Üí Control Tower ‚Üí Environments
  2. Click Create Environment, and enter your environment name (e.g., AgenticChatbot)

This environment will host your Joule Skills, including runtime logs, variables, and deployment status.

 

3. Create Actions

In Joule Studio, Actions define how your skill communicates with external systems ‚Äî in our case, the AI agent backend deployed on SAP AI Core. Each Action corresponds to a REST API endpoint. Let‚Äôs use /v2/plan as an example. Refer to this post to see how does this endpoint looks like. 

 

Step 1. Create an Action

In Joule Studio:

  • Go to Actions ‚Üí Create Action
  • Choose Build from Scratch (or upload an OpenAPI spec if you have one)

Step 2. Define Input

Click Input tab and define what data will send to your endpoint. 

Step 3. Define Output

Next, go to the Output tab. Here, we specify the response format expected from /v2/plan. This ensures Joule knows how to parse and display the backend's response properly. 

Step 4. Test and Connection

Now, open the Test tab and click Run Test with correct destination which we set up in previous step (1. Create Destination).

If the test passes successfully, click Release ‚Üí Publish Action. Your /v2/plan endpoint is now available for use in Joule Skill as an Action.

Step 5. Repeat for Other Endpoints 

Once you‚Äôve successfully connected /v2/plan, you can repeat the process for other endpoints. Each endpoint can be defined as a separate Action, giving you modular control over the entire workflow inside Joule Studio.

 

At this point, you‚Äôve completed all the backend connectivity steps, from creating destinations to validating the API in action. The groundwork is done.

üëâ  Next, we‚Äôll move to the fun part: turning this API into an interactive Joule Skill that we can use from chat interface. Let‚Äôs continue in Part 3 (2) Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release).

entry.title: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio ‚Äî Part 3 (2)
entry.content:
üöÄ Series Overview: Custom Agentic Chatbot with SAP AI Core and Joule Studio

  • Part 1 ‚Äî Building the Custom AI Agent Backend
  • Part 2 (1) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Environment & Containerization)
  • Part 2 (2) ‚Äî Deploying the Agent on AI Core (Deployment & Testing)
  • Part 3 (1) ‚Äî Setting Up Joule Studio Connection (Destination & Environment)
  • Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)
  • Part 3 (3) ‚Äî Testing and Sharing on Work Zone

 

Part 3 (2) ‚Äî Creating a Joule Skill (Design & Release)

 

In the previous part, we connected Joule Studio to our AI Core backend and tested the Action successfully. Now, it‚Äôs time to make it conversational. Now, we‚Äôll design the full conversational flow inside Joule Studio by creating a CustomAgent Skill that links together multiple backend actions

By the end of this section, you will:

  • Create a new Skill in Joule Studio
  • Configure its input parameters and message responses
  • Chain multiple Actions to form a complete conversational logic

Once the skill design is complete, we‚Äôll move on in Part 3 (3) to test it live in the Joule Chat Interface and deploy it to Work Zone for organization-wide access.

 

1. Create a Joule Skill

A Skill defines how Joule interprets user messages and which Actions to trigger in response. We'll now create a skill that connects your actions including /v2/plan action, so that the Joule chat interface can activate this skill and communicate seamlessly with your deployed AI Core backend. 

Step 1. Open the Lobby

Go to SAP Build Lobby ‚Üí Create ‚Üí Joule Skill. Name it something like Custom Agent, this will act as the main entry point of your agent. 

‚öôÔ∏è  Note: In Joule Studio, skills can be nested. Simply create your new skill inside that existing context.

Step 2. Define Skill Details

In the General tab, fill in the following fields as below example:

  • Name: CustomAgent
  • Description: A skill to activate custom agent. Activate this skill if user's request contains "/CustomAgent".

üí°  Tip: Use an explicit activation phrase (like /CustomAgent) to ensure the skill consistently triggers only when intended, making testing smoother and more predictable.

Also configure the toggles as follows:

  • Allow Joule to generate a response: Off ‚Üí You‚Äôll use ‚ÄúSend Message‚Äù steps instead.
  • Allow skill to be started directly by a user: On ‚Üí Enables direct triggering from the Joule chat interface.

 

Step 4. Configure Skill Parameters

Next, go to the Parameters tab and define the input variables that your skill will use.
For example:

  • conversation_id : Used to track continuous dialogue sessions (if not provided, the backend will start a new one)
  • message : The user‚Äôs actual input message

When parameters are defined at the skill level, Joule automatically parses values from the user‚Äôs chat input and makes them available as variables in subsequent nodes. This means you can reference them directly in your Action or Message nodes.

For example:

  • Use {{message}} when passing the user input to the to the /v2/plan or /v2/action-graph endpoint
  • Use {{conversation_id}} to maintain session context in AI Core side between user turns

You can also reuse the output of a previous Action in later nodes. For instance, if your /v2/plan Action returns a JSON object, its fields (like {{plan.content}}) can be referenced directly in the next Action or Send Message node. This lets your Joule Skill behave like a data pipeline, passing both user inputs and Action results through the workflow.

 

üóí  Example: Using Action Outputs in Message Nodes

This example below shows a  Message Configuration example where the output of the /v2/plan Action is referenced in the response message.

  • ${context.joule_action_...result.conversation_id} ‚Üí retrieves the conversation_id returned by the Action
  • ${context.joule_action_...result.content} ‚Üí displays the generated plan content returned by the Action
  • ${context.joule_action_...result.timestamp} ‚Üí shows the response time returned by the Action

 

Now that you‚Äôve seen how each Action and Message node exchanges data, let‚Äôs look at the entire Skill flow that ties them all together.

 

‚õì  CustomAgent skill flow design

This mechanism allows you to chain multiple Actions and build a natural, multi-step conversation flow such as:

/v2/plan ‚Üí /v2/action-graph ‚Üí /v2/start-execution ‚Üí /v2/continue-execution

Each Action node represents a backend call, while the Message nodes in between provide real-time feedback so users can monitor progress ‚Äî for example, confirming when the plan is created or when the execution starts.

To ensure a continuous and contextual conversation, each API call passes a shared conversation_id variable. This allow different endpoint (such as /v2/plan, /v2/action-graph, and /v2/continue-execution) to recognize they belong to the same dialogue session, maintaining conversation state consistently across multiple backend actions. 

When the user sends the same conversation_id in subsequent chats, the agent can continue the dialogue seamlessly from the previous state, effectively enabling multi-turn conversations across different endpoints. We'll demonstrate this continuous conversation flow in the next post.

 

Step 5. Release & Deploy Skill

Once the design is complete, click Release ‚Üí Create Version ‚Üí Deploy to your Environment.
After deployment, the skill becomes active in your Joule Studio environment, meaning it can now be invoked from the Joule Chat interface.

 

At this stage, your CustomAgent Skill has been fully structured - from defining parameters and linking actions to designing message nodes that visualize each execution step. You‚Äôve established the orchestration flow that allows Joule Studio to interact seamlessly with your AI Core agent.

üëâIn the next post, Part 3 (3): Testing and Sharing the Skill on Work Zone, we‚Äôll put this flow into action - testing real conversations, validating responses, and share your skill to Work Zone so users can access it as a live enterprise chatbot.

entry.title: Joule Skill for Maintenance Order Management in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is created to showcase the Joule Skills feature in SAP and is intended for demonstration purposes only. The content is not meant for productive use.

This use case demonstrates the creation and deployment of Joule Skills in SAP Build to manage Maintenance Orders in SAP S/4HANA. By leveraging APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, the solution enables users to create, update, and retrieve maintenance orders through natural language interactions in Joule. The setup involves configuring input parameters, mapping them to action calls, and formatting responses, all while securely connecting the SAP BTP environment to the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system via Cloud Connector. This provides a seamless, conversational interface for maintenance order management, highlighting the capabilities of Joule Skills for process automation and intelligent interaction.

Prerequisite

  1. Establish a secure tunnel between the SAP BTP subaccount and the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system in Cloud connector. This allows the Joule skill to communicate with backend services (such as the Maintenance Order APIs) hosted in the on-premise system.
  2. After configuring the Cloud Connector to establish connectivity between the SAP BTP environment and the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system, the next step is to create a destination in the BTP subaccount.
    This destination acts as a connection point that allows applications (such as Joule skills or process automation projects) to call on-premise APIs securely through the Cloud Connector.

Begin by creating a custom action and selecting the required API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This API will be integrated into the Joule Skill to enable Maintenance Order Management through action calls. Once the action is created, choose the available operations. For this demonstration, the Maintenance Order ‚Äì POST, UPDATE, and PATCH methods are used to perform create, update, and retrieve functions. After adding these actions, test each one using the test feature and select the destination configured in the BTP cockpit.

 

In SAP Build Lobby, create a Joule Skills project and provide a suitable description for the skill. For example:

Create individual Joule skills for Maintenance Order ‚Äì POST/UPDATE and PATCH operations.

Create Maintenance Orders

Set up the input parameters for this Joule Skill, which will be used in the prompt during the demo of maintenance order creation from Joule. Next, create a destination variable to ensure the destination is correctly mapped upon project deployment. Map all necessary values from the input parameters to the respective inputs of the action call used for creating a maintenance order. Finally, proceed to the last step to format the response in Joule using the ‚ÄòSend Message‚Äô option.

Get Maintenance Order ‚Äì Joule Skill

Change Maintenance Order ‚Äì Joule Skill (Same as above)

After this release and deploy the project in the environment.Once deployed the version is reflected and launch the Joule

So by deploying the created joule skills we now have this feature by using natural language.

In conclusion, this demonstration highlights how Joule Skills in SAP Build can simplify Maintenance Order Management by enabling intuitive, natural language interactions with SAP S/4HANA. Through seamless integration using the Cloud Connector and APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, business users can efficiently create, update, and retrieve maintenance orders without navigating complex interfaces.

Demo Link

entry.title: Early Adopter Care - Extend Latest People Profile with BTP Custom Cards
entry.content:
Extending People Profile with employee data that is specific to your company is something that a large majority of SuccessFactors customers do already. Getting a 360-degree view of the employee data is something that is at the heart of People Profile. With MDF custom objects, SAP SuccessFactors has always provided such in-app extension capability in People Profile and it is used by more than 75% of customers.  Now with the 2H 2025 release, we take this a step further and enable side-by-side extensions with custom UI integration cards, which allow to include employee data from BTP extensions in Latest People Profile.

Imagine i.e., you track asset inventory information of your employees in an extension application on BTP.  And you would like to have this information available for your employees, managers, or HR admins in the People Profile.  Including employee data available on BTP into Full Profile via custom UI integration cards is now supported with the 2H 2025 release for early adopter care customers. Please see the schematic picture of such side-by-side extensions:

What are some of the benefits of adding employee information from side-by-side BTP extensions to People Profile:

  • Extensions built on BTP are much more flexible than in-app extensions. You have full control over the application logic with SAP Build and over the user experience with flexible UI patterns of SAP Fiori.
  • Nevertheless, you have a deep integration into People Profile where the user is not cognizant about where the data is coming from.
  • All relevant employee data is available for employees, managers, HR admins in one place, the People Profile.

How can you make it happen? You have an extension application running on SAP BTP that provides an API that lets you access the data stored in the application. To make the information available in SuccessFactors People Profile, you extend People Profile with the Extensibility Wizard, which you start from Configure Latest People Profile. The Extensibility Wizard will create a project in SAP Business Application Studio, where you implement the UI integration card, connect the API of the extension application to the custom card, and deploy it to SuccessFactors.  Once deployed, the card can be added to Full Profile in any category. With that, data stored on BTP will become available in Latest People Profile. Please see this screen shot with the custom UI integration card:

If you have BTP-based extensions with employee data that you would like to make available in People Profile, then you are a candidate for our Early Adopter Care program, which starts with the 2H 2025 release in November 2025. If you are interested in this new possibility to extend People Profile as an early adopter care customer, please contact @stockp via direct message here in the community or via email to peter.stock@sap.com. We can provide you additional material around this capability and start the qualification for this program.

Take advantage of this opportunity for your company to engage directly with SAP development and the product management team. As part of this initiative, you will have the opportunity to actively participate in shaping the functionality over the next several months until it becomes generally available (GA). Registration will open soon with the production release of 2H 2025 version of SuccessFactors.

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and Joule agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

As Skill Builder in Joule Studio is General Available, many early adopters and interested teams are asking the same essential question: "How to get Joule Studio?"

Whether you're a business decision-maker assessing impact, a developer organizing your technical landscape, or a partner helping your customer, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Before diving into the setup, it's essential to take a moment to review the commercialization details. It is crucial to ensure that you have the correct plans and SKUs in place for building and executing Joule Skills effectively. Understanding these components will set a solid foundation for a successful implementation.

Let's get started!

 

Pre-Requisites for Customers

SAP Build

    • The SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311) is required to build, test, and deploy your custom Joule Skills.
    • The new unified SAP Build commercial model is now live across all four models: 
      • Subscription 
      • BTPEA - Business Technology Platform Enterprise Agreement (since August 11)
      • PAYG - Pay As You Go (since August 11)
      • CPEA - Cloud Platform Enterprise Agreement (NEW ‚Äì September 17) 

Joule

    • You will need to have Joule (base or higher) - Joule Base (SKU 8019544) or Joule Premium (SKU 8019164) (Includes AI Units)
    • Joule Studio works  with any Joule brownfield license, except Joule for Consultants and Joule for Developers.

Commercial Details

There is no additional cost for orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

That said, it‚Äôs important to note that while the orchestration and invocation of a custom skill is free, the underlying components used by your custom Joule Skills will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule skill kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation will still be billed according to the Business Technology Platform Enterprise Agreement pricing structure.

 

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Customer Starting Points and Required Steps

 This table outlines the five primary customer scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA  in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you‚Äôre starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The customer is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The customer already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  • Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement/subscription is on the build-default plan (standard is not compatible).
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The customer has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The customer already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The customer has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
 

Some Questions 

  • I don't have SAP Build! What to do? 
       Initial setup of SAP Build
  • Which license do I need to access Joule Studio? 
       SAP Build Default plan 
  • How can I upgrade my SAP Build Standard Plan to Build Default plan? 
       Change Plan
  • I don't have Joule! What do I do?  
       Initial Setup for Joule
  • How do I run Joule Booster? 
       Instructions to Run Booster 

Helpful Resources for Setup and Activation 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio
  • Provisioning Joule Studio 
  • Enabling Joule Studio for existing customers 
  • Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Reference Architecture for Joule Studio 

Expert Insights

  • If your existing SBPA is on a "Standard" plan, you must upgrade it to the "Build Default" plan before attempting to link it with Joule Studio.
  • Reference Architecture 
    In the picture below, Joule and SBPA are configured within the same subaccount. However, they can also be set up in different subaccounts or even across separate global accounts.
    But in case Joule and SBPA are both in different global accounts, this is also possible, but with the same Cloud Identity Service for both accounts.

entry.title: Developing Mobile Apps with AI Agents: Introducing the MCP Server for mobile development kit
entry.content:
Updated 16 Oct 2025: the setup has been simplified as the @sap/mdk-mcp-server is now also available on npmjs.com

Are you an experienced developer working on mobile app projects based on SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK)? Do you want to jumpstart your mobile app development with MDK?  Do you use AI agents such as Cursor, Cline, OpenCode, or GitHub Copilot to support you in your daily work? Wouldn't it be cool if the agent could help you develop MDK applications? We now offer some free tools that can provide more context about your project as well as relevant MDK examples to steer the AI coding assistant in doing the right thing.

Figure 1: High level overview MDK MCP Server

 We are excited to announce the release of the MCP server for mobile development kit. This open-source server provides AI agents with comprehensive MDK knowledge and tools. By combining best practice guidelines, project-aware context information, templates for creating new projects, and access to the MDK CLI tools, the MDK MCP server transforms AI agents into MDK development experts.

The code repository is located at  https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server

This MDK specific release follows previously announced MCP servers by SAP for:

  • CAP
  • Fiori
  • UI5

What is an MCP Server?

An Model Context Protocol (MCP) server is designed to manage and deliver capabilities to Large Language Models (LLMs) via AI agents. It bridges the gap between LLMs and external resources such as services, tools, and data, enabling LLMs to interact with these resources.

What is mobile development kit?

The SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) is a powerful framework that enables developers to build cross-platform mobile applications using a metadata-driven approach. It is part of SAP Business Technology Platform and integrates tightly with SAP Mobile Services.

Some of SAP‚Äôs larger and complex mobile apps are built using MDK. An example is SAP Service and Asset Manager.

Why should you use this MCP server?

The newly introduced MCP server for mobile development kit transforms AI agents into MDK development experts. It provides context-focused tools that aim to help the AI agent to answer questions such as:

  • Finding examples of using an MDK component.
  • Retrieving details about specific properties of an MDK component.
  • Finding the schema for a specific MDK component.
  • Searching MDK documentation.

Other reasons for using this MCP server:

  • Large Language Models (LLMs) sometimes lack information on the latest best practices and metadata recommended for MDK development.
  • They might recommend the use of MDK metadata that does not exist in the version your project is using, or MDK metadata that has been marked as deprecated.
  • By facilitating MDK validation tools, your coding agent can validate the changes it has made, ensuring it follows current best practices.
  • Scaffolding tools can help agents kickstart new projects faster and with established patterns, saving token costs.

The MCP server can help you answer questions you as a developer have about the project you are working on, such as:

  • Explain what this specific file does in the MDK project structure.
  • How can I use Fragments in my project?
  • Can this application support offline capabilities?
  • Are there any requirements for the data source to support offline?

Combining AI agents with existing tools ‚Äì a powerful and efficient combination

Instead of relying fully on what an AI agent can generate, we offer the agent access to existing tools in our MDK toolset.

Figure 2: Tools used by the MCP Server for mobile development kit

With MDK tools, we can migrate, validate, build and deploy projects. With the MDK Generator, we provide project scaffolding for Base, Empty, List-Detail and CRUD templates. Based on your prompts, we can further generate pages and actions to your MDK project. This ensures a more predictable outcome, saves time and tokens (costs).

Open Source

We are also happy to announce that the MCP Server for mobile development kit is an open-source project, licensed under the Apache-2.0 license. Learn more about open source at SAP.

We are curious to see what you will do with our MCP server for mobile development kit ! Please do not hesitate to provide your feedback here or report any issues in our GitHub repository.

Setup

Assuming you have already installed node.js on your machine, first install Yeoman. This must be an older version of Yeoman to avoid compatibility issues.

npm install -g yo@4.3.1

For installing the MDK MCP server, we offer two options:

1. Use npm to install it from the public npmjs registry at https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/mdk-mcp-server .

npm install -g @sap/mdk-mcp-server

2. Clone the open-source code repository at https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server, and use npm to install it:

git clone https://github.com/SAP/mdk-mcp-server.git
cd mdk-mcp-server
npm i --include=optional

npm i -g /mdk-mcp-server@.‚Äã

Both MDK Tools (@sap/mdk-tools) as well as MDK Generator (@sap/generator-mdk) will automatically be installed as dependencies of the MCP server for mobile development kit.

Next, your MCP client (AI agent) needs to be configured to make use of the server. Depending on the AI agent used, the configuration looks a little different. We are still waiting for alignment across AI agents regarding this kind of configuration.

In general, the mcpServers configuration should include the following section:

     "mdk-mcp": {
      "command": "mdk-mcp",
      "args": []
    }


Once installed, the AI agent in your IDE will automatically gain access to the MDK MCP server and can start using the tools at its own discretion. Depending on your IDE and settings, you may need to approve the first tool calls.

Figure 3: MCP Servers configuration in Cline

 

Rules

The following rules help guide the agent to use the server correctly.

## Guidelines for MDK
Don‚Äôt generate .service.metadata file
Don‚Äôt generate .xml file in ‚ÄòServices‚Äô folder
Don‚Äôt change .project.json file


Add these rules to your existing global or project-specific AGENTS.md (specifics may vary based on respective MCP client).

Figure 4: MDK specific rules configuration in Cline

 

Tools

This release of the MDK MCP server includes the following tools, which can be accessed by your AI agent:

Tool name

Description

mdk-gen-project

Generates a new MDK project in the current directory.

mdk-gen-i18n

Returns a prompt to generate i18n files for MDK project describing the texts, labels and messages.

mdk-gen-databinding-page

Returns a prompt to generate a databinding-enabled MDK page describing the page layout, controls and data bindings.

mdk-gen-layout-page

Generates a layout-based MDK page. You can describe the page layout, controls.

mdk-gen-entity

Generates CRUD or List Detail template metadata for a new entity set.

mdk-gen-action

Returns a prompt to generate an MDK action describing the action type and data bindings.

mdk-build

Build an MDK project.

mdk-deploy

Deploy an MDK project to SAP Mobile Services.

mdk-show-qrcode

Show QR code for an MDK application.

mdk-migrate

Migrate an MDK project to the latest MDK schema version.

mdk-validate

Validate an MDK project.

mdk-search-documentation

Returns the top N results from MDK documentation by semantic search, sorted by relevance.

mdk-get-component-documentation

Returns the schema of an MDK component based on the name of the component.

mdk-get-property-documentation

Returns the documentation of a specific property of an MDK component.

mdk-get-example

Returns an example usage of an MDK component.

mdk-open-mobile-app-editor

Returns instructions on how to open the Mobile App Editor to create the ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù file.

 

 

Integration with SAP Mobile Services

For the integration with SAP Mobile Services, the MCP server currently makes use of the Cloud Foundry CLI and a service metadata file that contains details about:

  1. The mobile application defined in the SAP Mobile Services instance.
  2. The OData service metadata of the data source used in the mobile application. This describes the data model and capabilities of the OData service.

An example of such a service metadata file (with filename ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù) is provided in our code repository. However, changing this file is not easy. We offer a tool to help with creating or updating this file as part of our Visual Studio Code extension: Mobile development kit extension for Visual Studio Code

How to use this tool to create or update the ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù file:

1. Install Mobile development kit extension for Visual Studio Code version 1.32.0 or later in your Visual Studio Code.

2. Make sure you have installed the Cloud Foundry CLI.

3. Make sure to log in to your SAP Business Technology Platform environment on Cloud Foundry. This can be done by executing the following command in a terminal window:

cf login <your target endpoint> --sso

For more details you can refer to this help documentation.

4. Open the Command Palette in Visual Studio Code and select the "MDK: Open Mobile App Editor" command.

Figure 5: MDK: Open Mobile App Editor

5. Create/Select a new/existing mobile app.

Figure 6: Mobile Application Editor in Visual Studio Code

6. Select a destination.

7. Click "Add App to Project" button.

We also offer a tool in the MCP server to provide you the above information through the agent. You can basically ask the agent how to create the ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù file.

In future releases we aim to enhance and further simplify the integration with SAP Mobile Services.

What can you do with this server?

The MCP server for mobile development kit works well for everyday tasks in MDK projects. It can help you refactor your code and metadata and add new features.

Important: Our MCP Server for mobile development kit is designed to support professional developers in their daily work. As with all AI-generated information, you should check the generated results carefully to avoid unintended side effects. As a professional developer, YOU are in control and responsible for the outcome.

Some examples where this MCP server can help

Update old projects

I‚Äôve opened an old project that I‚Äôve created in one of my previous blog post series. I know the MDK metadata schema is outdated and want to update it. I‚Äôll ask Cline which tool can be used for this. As you can see in the screenshot, Cline made use of the MCP server for MDK to find out which tool to be used and is now proactively asking to run the MDK migration tool.

Figure 7: Update old MDK project in Cline

Explain specific properties

In the screenshot below, I am using Cursor and asked what the property ‚ÄúAnimated‚Äù does in an Action.

Figure 8: Get explanation of a property in Cursor

Help to deploy the app

Making use of the available tools, the AI agent can help you deploy the mobile app and provide detailed information on how to install the app on your device.

Figure 9a: Deployment - validate and build the app in Cursor 

Figure 9b: Deployment - deploy and show QR code in Cursor 

Figure 9c: Deployment - Summary and installation instructions in Cursor

Conclusion

In this blog post we have introduced new tools to help professional developers in their everyday tasks developing MDK apps. We have made the tools as open as possible, to allow developers to use their favorite agentic development environment. As a developer, you should be able to develop SAP mobile apps in whatever environment you prefer to use.

We are also providing the MCP server as open source, allowing you to modify the tool to your needs and contribute enhancements.

As always, feedback is welcome to improve the blog posts, but most importantly the tools and products involved.

entry.title: Vibe Coding a Mobile App to display Business Partners
entry.content:
Updated 28 October 2025: Added easier configuration option through Cursor's MCP directory.

Last week I posted about the release of the MCP server for mobile development kit. In that post, I‚Äôve provided details about the setup and offered some simple use cases as examples. In this post, I will be using the Cursor coding agent together with the MCP server for mobile development kit to vibe code a mobile app from scratch.

We are going to create a simple mobile app that shows a list of Business Partners. The sample data is stored in an S/4HANA Cloud instance made available through SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

It is important to note that while Cursor is featured in this example, SAP is evaluating several coding agents to ensure broad compatibility with our MCP server. This demonstration does not imply preference or endorsement of any particular product.

We will go through the following steps:

  1. Select a data source
  2. Configure the app in SAP Mobile Services and add a connection to the data source
  3. Ensure we can access the Cloud Foundry space where our SAP Mobile Services instance is running
  4. Use Cursor
    1. Configure the coding agent
    2. Add MDK Editor extension
    3. Retrieve details about mobile app and data source in SAP Mobile Services
  5. Start vibe coding!

Picking a data source from SAP Business Accelerator Hub

We start with opening SAP Business Accelerator Hub and browsing to the Business Partner API overview. This is an API available on the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. We are going to use this API for our mobile app. To set up the connection in SAP Mobile Services, we need to gather some information.

Select Show API Key and copy the key.

In the Configuration Details tab, you will find the SANDBOX URL. Copy this URL.

Configuring the mobile app in the SAP Mobile Services Admin cockpit

Assuming you have an instance of SAP Mobile Services available in your SAP BTP subaccount, open the Mobile Services Admin cockpit.  You can do this via Service Marketplace, select Mobile Services and open the Support link. There is no need to create an instance here.

If you don‚Äôt have the service yet, simply add the Mobile Services entitlement to your subaccount. If you‚Äôve created a brand-new subaccount, then make sure to enable Cloud Foundry, add the Cloud Foundry Runtime entitlement and allocate some runtime memory (1 unit is sufficient). You will also need an active Cloud Foundry space.

In the Mobile Services Admin cockpit, navigate to the Mobile Applications > Native/MDK tab and click New. Select Mobile Development Kit (MDK) as the type of application. Click Next.

Provide details about the app.

Click Next and leave the remaining configuration steps unchanged. Select Finish after reviewing the selections.

Once the app definition is created, select Connectivity.

We will now set up a connection to the data service we‚Äôve found in SAP Business Accelerator Hub. We first provide information about the Destination Name and Destination Type (Internet Destination).

For the URL, paste the URL you‚Äôve copied from SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Click Next.

Create a custom header called apikey and paste the API key you‚Äôve obtained from Business Accelerator Hub into the Header Value field.

For the remaining steps, leave all settings as default and click Next and finally Finish.

Access your Cloud Foundry environment

To be able to exchange information between your (local) development environment and your SAP Mobile Services instance, you need to log in to your BTP environment on Cloud Foundry. Make sure you have installed the Cloud Foundry CLI.

The easiest way to log in is to use the following command and follow the instructions to open the provided url:

cf  login <your target endpoint> --sso

Your target endpoint is visible on the Overview page of your BTP subaccount.

 

Using Cursor

Configuring the coding agent

We‚Äôll open Cursor, where we have configured the mdk-mcp server. Detailed instructions can be found at https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/mdk-mcp-server.

Update: our MCP server for mobile development kit is now also listed in Cursor's Model Context Protocol (MCP) directory. Simply click the "+ Add to Cursor" button to configure it.

For Cursor, you'll find the MCP servers in the Cursor Settings > Tools & MCP. You can enable or disable MCP servers as needed. My recommendation is to only enable those MCP servers that are needed to perform a specific tasks. Having too many tools active could confuse the agent and LLM. Our team is currently working to consolidate a number of tools.

Installing the MDK Extension

As Cursor does not offer a direct way to download and install extensions from Microsoft's Visual Studio Marketplace, we will need to manually download and install the MDK Extension (VSIX). There are a few options. The easiest one is opening VSCode, search for "mdk" in the Extensions: Marketplace pane and select the "mobile development kit extension for Visual Studio Code". Click the gear icon and select Download VSIX from the dropdown menu.

Drop the downloaded VSIX file into the Cursor workspace, right click the file and select "Install Extension VSIX".

Alternatively, you can download the extension via me.sap.com at the following link (log in and download permissions required).

Retrieving the mobile application details

For our project, we need to collect information about the mobile app definition and mobile destination we've created earlier. In Cursor, go to the Command Palette and open ‚ÄúMDK: Open Mobile Application Editor‚Äù

 

The Mobile Application editor opens. Select the application we‚Äôve created in SAP Mobile Services and tick the box of the destination.

By clicking ‚ÄúAdd App to Project‚Äù, we collect all relevant information into a file named ‚Äú.service.metadata‚Äù. This information will be used to create the mobile application project in the next steps.

Let‚Äôs get mobile vibe coding!

We are now ready to start creating the mobile application. We type the following prompt in the agent‚Äôs chat pane:

Create a mobile application to browse the list of Business Partners. 
Besides updating the generated README.md file, do not create documentation.
Make sure there are no linting errors and validate the project.

Note: I‚Äôve specifically mentioned to skip creating documentation. This is because this agent, combined with Claude Sonnet 4.5, is very keen on creating documentation. Although this is a good practice, it can cause issues with bundling our metadata. There is also no need to ‚Äòburn‚Äô more tokens than necessary.

After a few iterations, the application and README.md file has been created.

To test what has been generated so far, we will deploy the application to SAP Mobile Services.

Open a new chat and enter the prompt

Deploy the application

Based on the information retrieved from the MCP server, the agent will trigger a deployment to SAP Mobile Services and show a QR code that we can use for onboarding the SAP Mobile Services client application. This client can be downloaded from the App Store and Google Play.

‚ÄÉ

The mobile app looks like this on iPhone:

 

The app runs fine. However, the partner list shows mainly record id numbers. We also notice this number get repeated in the list. Can we change this without touching any of the code or metadata? You don‚Äôt need to be an MDK expert to enhance the app. Your agent can help!

We use the following prompts:

Change the Business Partners list to show their name and search term 
instead of business partner id and customer id.
Change the subhead to BusinessPartnerGrouping.
On the list page, change the title to ‚ÄúBusiness Partner Overview‚Äù

The main page also looks like we are pulling the information straight out of a database. Let‚Äôs fix that.

On the main page, change the title to My Business Partners, 
change the "vibe_coded_demoapp" text to "Vibe coding showcase", 
change "A_BusinessPartner" to "Show list of Business Partners"

The level of detail on the page varies based on the agent and LLM; sometimes it's very detailed, while smarter agents produce more compact pages. In my example, there's too much information for mobile viewing.

To make the detail page more compact, please remove the 
relationship sections (to_<name>) and reduce the visible fields.
On the detail page, change the title to "Business Partner Details"

The object header on the detail page could look a bit better if we change the contents.
‚ÄÉ

On the detail page, change the title to "Business Partner Details" 
and in the object header, please show the following items: 

headline = full name
subhead = id
BodyText = organization name
footnote = search item
Description = form of address
Status text = is blocked
substatus text = category

After the agent makes the changes, the resulting app is deployed and looks a bit a better:

 

We can even ask the agent to review the app and make it look even better. For this use case, I‚Äôve provided screenshots of the main page, the list page and the detail page and prompted:

Can you make the main/list/detail page look more professional

After several iterations, and reminding the agent to consult the MDK documentation, we have an app the indeed looks better. For the main page, I‚Äôve also asked to add an image with the SAP logo.


Short summary of the changes made for each page:

  • Main page
    • Added branding footer toolbar
    • Added logo image
    • Improved button design
    • Added welcome section
    • Added brief key features overview
  • List page
    • Circular avatars
    • Blue accent color
    • Improved search bar
  • Detail page
    • Cleaner object header
    • Split the long list into logical sections
    • Improved layout
    • Better visual hierarchy

 

Thoughts

For those unfamiliar with MDK and the tools we provide, it might look like magic to create a mobile app like this one. However, before the arrival of coding agents we already offered generators that offered scaffolding. The AI coding agent makes use of the same tools to create the app. What has changed is that instead of the developer continuing to enhance the project manually, it is now the coding assistant doing most of these changes based on the prompts provided by the developer.

In some cases, I‚Äôve noticed the agent makes wrong assumptions and does not consult the information made available through the MCP server. An example of this is regarding the CSS styling. The agent assumed full support for CSS styling, like available in modern HTML5-based web apps. However, MDK offers limited support for styling. Without checking the documentation, the agent created styles that had no effect. I had to remind the agent to check the documentation first (maybe we should create a rule for this).

Practical recommendation: It is better to start every task in a separate chat with your agent to keep the context window small. This will help creating better results and less hallucinations.

Conclusion

Developing a mobile app based on Mobile Development Kit is now faster and easier thanks to AI coding agents. By introducing the MCP server for mobile development kit, we ensure coding agents can tap into knowledge and best practices that LLMs have not been trained on (yet).

Depending on the coding agent and LLM used, your results may vary. The development still needs supervision. Always review what the coding agent produces and make adjustments where needed.

As always, feedback is welcome.

entry.title: Exciting UX talks at TechEd ‚Äì Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia)
entry.content:
For TechEd 2025 we have an exciting agenda lined up for all of you interested in SAP user experience. We not only have many interesting talks and hands-on sessions for creators (designer and developers) but also some talks showing our strategy and latest innovations for end users ‚Äì which hopefully will inspire you when creating your own applications!

With TechEd Virtual, you can watch some of these talks from wherever you are around the world. Here‚Äôs an overview of the talks which are primarily relevant for user experience, starting with TechEd Virtual, and then moving on to the individual locations.

For TechEd Virtual, Berlin and Bangalore: the main sub-tracks to look out for are:

  • Product and User Experience,
    in the Cloud Application (CA) track.
  • AI-driven user experiences with SAP Build,
    in the Application Development and Automation (AD) track.

TechEd Virtual

  • ST112v | AI and the future of product and user experience on the web and mobile (Strategy Talk ‚Äì 25 Min.)
  • CA201v | Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System (Deep Dive ‚Äì 45 Min.)
  • ST116v | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools (Strategy Talk ‚Äì 25 Min.)
  • AD106v | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build (Deep Dive ‚Äì 45 Min.)
  • AD820v | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions (Road Map ‚Äì 25 Min.)

 

TechEd Berlin (and Bangalore)

All the sessions below are taking place in TechEd Berlin, and also TechEd On Tour Bangalore except the strategy sessions (which is available on-demand via TechEd Virtual), and the demo stations, since Bangalore has a different approach to providing demos.

Cloud Applications - Product and User Experience

  • ST112 | AI and the future of product and user experience on the web and mobile - Strategy Talk
  • CA811 | User and product experience innovations by SAP‚Äîon the web and mobile - Road Map
  • CA201 | Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System - Deep Dive
  • CA261 | Create great UX with AI, SAP Design System, SAP Fiori elements, and SAPUI5 ‚Äì Hands-On
  • CA105 | Intelligent app development at scale with AI and SAP Fiori elements ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • CA262 | Analyze and optimize front-end application performance ‚Äì Hands-on
  • CA200 | An overview of our AI-enhanced mobile products across SAP Business Suite - Deep Dive
  • AD170 | Build scalable enterprise mobile solutions with SAP Build - Hands-on

In addition to the above talks, you can come and visit us at our demo station:

  • CA914 | AI-based user and product experience innovations on the web and mobile ‚Äì Demo station

Application Development and Automation

  • ST117 | SAP‚Äôs user experience strategy with SAP Build ‚Äì Strategy
  • ST116 | SAP Build for all: A shift toward AI-assisted developer-centric tools ‚Äì Strategy
  • AD818 | Explore the road map for user experience with SAP Build ‚Äì Road Map
  • AD820 | Future of app dev in SAP Build: Simplifying clean core and LoB extensions
  • AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD166 | Taking UI to the next level: Develop SAPUI5 with SAP Build ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD200 | Unlocking the full potential of business users with SAP Build ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD165 | Build it yourself: Your modern digital workplace ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD100 | SAP Joule for developers: How AI can boost your development in SAP Build ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD160 | Get hands-on with Joule: Boost your SAP Build development with AI ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD201 | Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it for ABAP developers ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD163 | Fusion development with ABAP Cloud in SAP Build ‚Äì Hands-on
  • AD203 | Fact-checking UI extensibility on cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you ‚Äì Deep Dive
  • AD260 | UI extensibility on top of cloud and ABAP: What's in it for you ‚Äì Hands-on

The corresponding demo station is:

AD901 | SAP Build: AI agents, automations, and digital workspaces ‚Äì Demo station

For a comprensive overview of sessions relevant for SAPUI5 developers, including the abstracts, look at:

  • Join SAPUI5 Sessions at SAP TechEd 2025

Similarly, for an overview of all the sessions of interest for mobile development, including abstracts, see:

  • SAP TechEd 2025 - Go Mobile!!!

Joule and Agentic AI is of course also relevant for creating a great user experience, here are some recommended deep dives:

  • AI100 | Build custom AI solutions with the generative AI hub
  • AI103 | Integrating Joule with other tools such as WalkMe and Microsoft 365 Copilot
  • AI105 | Building custom AI agents and skills with Joule Studio

Usability Testing sessions on-site in Berlin

You can sign up to test one of these interesting topics in Berlin:

  1. Exploring Joule and voice ‚Äì understanding mobile AI in your daily work
  2. Redesigning the dashboard building experience with SAP Analytics Cloud
  3. Building AI agents with Joule Studio in SAP Build
  4. Vibe coding with SAP Build
  5. Accelerate your cloud implementation: Business configuration templates in SAP Central Business Configuration
  6. Supercharge your SAP Fiori elements app development with SAP Fiori tools and AI

Find out more and register for testing!

 

TechEd On Tour USA

ASUG Tech Connect  November 4 ‚Äì 6 in Louisville, Kentucky has a number of interesting talks and hands-on sessions for you. These are my selection of sessions related to SAP Fiori:

  • Creating Better User Experiences with AI-Powered SAP Fiori Apps
  • Using Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development
  • Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP
  • Explore ABAP Cloud in SAP Build: What's in it For ABAP Developers
  • Customer Show and Tell: From CDS View to Fiori Launchpad: Full-Stack Development with Eclipse ADT with Naturipe

Here are my selected Hands-on Lab sessions:

  • Get Started with ABAP Cloud for Classic ABAP Developers
  • Hands-on Lab: Explore Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities
  • Hands-on Lab: Build On-Stack Extensions with ABAP Cloud in SAP Cloud ERP

This blog post by Peter Spielvogel, who is a speaker there, gives an overview including abstracts:

  • UX and application development with AI at ASUG Tech Connect 2025 a companion event to SAP TechEd.

 

TechEd On Tour Australia

Mastering SAP, Sydney November 12 ‚Äì 14 in Sydney has these UX talks for you, each 45 minutes. The first one is unique to Sydney, by Jocelyn Dart, the other four are the same as in Berlin and Bangalore:

  • AD300 | SAP User Experience is the foundation for AI and Clean Core
  • AD301 | AI for App Development at Scale with SAP Design System & SAP Fiori Elements
  • AD302 | AI-Assisted User Experience Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP
  • AD106 | The art and science of SAPUI5 in SAP Build
  • AD200 | Unlocking the Full Potential of Business Users with SAP Build

These AI-related talks also sound relevant for UX:

  • AD202 | Agent building 101: All that you can do with Joule Studio
  • DT105 | SAP Business AI in SAP Cloud ERP

 

I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, giving the strategy talk, the road map talk and a deep-dive talk about creating apps with the SAP Design System (ST112,  CA811 and CA201 respectively).

  • Looking forward to meeting you!

entry.title: Customers and Partners Innovate Without Limits on SAP BTP with SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build
entry.content:
Across industries and around the world, organizations are discovering new possibilities with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). By connecting their business ecosystem, building apps, and automating processes with intelligence, they‚Äôre driving faster innovation and growth.

With SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build, companies can easily connect systems, create applications quickly, and automate processes with AI, unlocking value and agility like never before.

Here are some of the ways customers and partners are driving transformation with SAP BTP.

Olam Agri: Unlocking Cash Flow and Real-Time Insights

  • Global agri-business Olam Agri (S$33.2 billion in annual revenue) transformed its finance operations with SAP BTP.
  • In just nine months, Olam Agri migrated from ECC to RISE with SAP on AWS, covering 35 countries and 90 entities.
  • Using SAP Integration Suite, the company established real-time bank connectivity and freed S$250 million in treasury cash.
  • With SAP Build, Olam Agri created cost-tracking apps that deliver near-real-time visibility across its global operations.

üìΩÔ∏è Watch the Olam Agri Story to see how connected finance drives results.

  • With SAP Integration Suite, Visa connected its global payment network directly to SAP systems, enabling automated reconciliation and direct invoice payments.
  • Using SAP Build, the team delivered a smooth in-app payment experience from concept to go-live in just six months.

üìΩÔ∏è Watch the Visa Story to see how embedded finance accelerates business.

ABeam Consulting: Driving Intelligent Enterprise Innovation

  • With more than 9,000 consultants across Asia, ABeam Consulting delivers end-to-end SAP transformations across SAP ERP Cloud, SuccessFactors, Ariba, and Concur.
  • Leveraging SAP BTP with SAP Integration Suite and SAP Build, ABeam helps customers integrate complex system landscapes while extending business processes with rapid application development that leverages AI and Joule-powered automation.

Mamee: Building Agility and Modernizing Operations

cbs Consulting: Partnering for Continuous Innovation

  • cbs Consulting develops smart extensions, automates processes, and connects SAP and non-SAP systems with SAP Build and SAP Integration Suite. Its accelerators help customers reduce technical debt and streamline migrations to SAP S/4HANA.

Now It's Your Turn to Innovate Without Limits

entry.title: UX and application development with AI at ASUG Tech Connect 2025 a companion event to SAP TechEd
entry.content:
This year, SAP TechEd has several options to allow you to learn about the latest SAP technologies and how to apply them to your organization. In addition to TechEd in Berlin and the virtual option, there are ‚ÄúSAP TechEd On Tour‚Äù events in Louisville, Sydney, and Bangalore. In this post, I‚Äôll share the sessions on application development and user experience that we are presenting at ASUG Tech Connect in Louisville, Kentucky. As you would expect many have AI -assisted capabilities to make both business users and developers more productive.

 

At ASUG Tech Connect, we have both lectures and hands-on workshops.

Lectures are a chance to hear from SAP experts and have your questions answered in the room.

Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP (Jens Weiler)
Explore on-stack key user and developer tools in the ABAP Cloud development model, now enhanced with generative AI. Extend standard apps and manage custom ones in SAP Cloud ERP and explore transactional, analytical, and integration use cases like the extensibility AI assistant, queries for analytical SAP Fiori apps, and SQL services.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 11:15 AM-12:05 PM

What‚Äôs Next: AI-First Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite (Ullas Holla, Peter Spielvogel)
Get a fast-paced look at how SAP is embedding AI and delivering cross-suite innovations that break down silos and speed up decision-making. We‚Äôll cover the latest highlights from releases of SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite‚Äîplus give you a sneak peek at what‚Äôs coming in 2026 and beyond.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 3:30 PM-4:20 PM

Customer Show and Tell: From CDS View to Fiori Launchpad: Full-Stack Development with Eclipse ADT with Naturipe (Brian Galloway, Dario Cruz)
This session covers the end-to-end development workflow in the RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition environment using Eclipse ABAP Development Tools (ADT). It demonstrates how to define a data source and expose it via a CDS view, enabling consumption through SAP Fiori elements, Eclipse ADT, and Postman. A live demo illustrates the creation of a simple SAPUI5 application that consumes the same OData service and is deployed to the SAP Fiori Launchpad, showcasing full-stack integration from backend data modeling to frontend delivery.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 8:00 AM-9:30 AM

Using Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development (Ullas Holla)
AI changes everything, especially for developing business applications. See how SAP‚Äôs latest coding agents let you build SAP Fiori elements apps using a conversational interface. Create apps using Joule, including a CAP service, sample data, and SAPUI5 customizations.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 4:10 PM-5:00 PM

Creating Better User Experiences with AI-Powered SAP Fiori Apps (Peter Spielvogel)
Discover how the latest AI features in SAP Fiori apps enhance user productivity and streamline onboarding. Starting with My Home and diving into commonly used SAP Fiori apps, see how AI simplifies information access, supports informed business decisions, and fosters seamless collaboration. Explore how conversational interactions are making SAP more intuitive than ever.
Thursday, November 6, 2025, 4:15 PM-5:05 PM

Hands-on workshops give you the opportunity to test the latest SAP innovations and gain access to the same tools and technologies we use to build apps for SAP S/4HANA.

Familiar with classic ABAP development? Explore how similar development works with ABAP Cloud using the ABAP RESTful application programming model. Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 1:10 PM-3:10 PM

Hands-on Lab: Explore Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities

Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 8:00 AM-10:00 AM

Discover how to build extensions, applications, and services with the ABAP Cloud development model, using the ABAP RESTful application programming model and generative AI. Practice clean core extensibility in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Learn how to govern clean core development using the ABAP test cockpit, and how to use the ABAP Cloud development model and clean core extensibility principles to modernize your custom on-stack extensions.
